awd_titl_txt: A Fundamental Study on Energy Efficient Wireless Communication Networks: Modeling,  Algorithms, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The rapid development and wide deployment of wireless networks incur a fast escalation of energy demand, which eagerly calls for energy-efficient networking techniques. At the same time, wireless networks are evolving into complex forms with multi-dimensional resources including communication link, radio, channel, antenna, and transmit power; algorithms with low complexity for energy efficiency optimization are highly demanded. This project targets at a fundamental study on energy-efficient wireless networking through establishment of a uniformed analytical framework, development of efficient and low-complexity algorithms, and application of the generic studies into important scenarios in the fifth generation (5G) cellular systems. This interdisciplinary research will not only provide various training projects to undergraduate and graduate studies, but also inspire students to pursue high-quality research with a creative, open-minded, and cross-disciplinary perspective.
 
This project is going to demonstrate that a uniformed multidimensional optimization framework for energy efficiency optimization can be constructed by the principle of scheduling proper transmission patterns, which are defined by the interference model of the network. With such a uniformed optimization model, low-complexity decomposition techniques are fundamentally related to a maximum weighted transmission pattern (MWTP) problem, under a physical interference model according to the signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio. Approximation algorithms and associated performance analysis for the MWTP problem (which is NP-hard in general) are critical research issues to be studied. Distributed algorithms for solving the energy efficiency optimization problem further involves decomposition with multi-objective optimization, and innovative Lyapunov function design and associated stability analysis under the physical interference model, which will also be addressed in this project. Energy efficient solutions in a couple of important 5G cellular scenarios will be enabled through innovative modeling and algorithms in the uniformed multidimensional framework, including joint optimization that incorporates massive MIMO interference mitigation with flow constraint at network layer and base station sleeping at system level, formulation and algorithm development for a MWTP problem under the massive MIMO interference model, and modeling of the interplay between massive MIMO and device-to-device communications. In this project, the proposed research seamlessly integrates studies in the areas of optimization, graph theory, dual decomposition, approximation algorithms, and wireless communication and networking.  The research outcomes are expected to provide important guidance for the development of the 5G cellular systems.

por.por_cntn:
The rapid development and wide deployment of wireless networks has incurred a fast escalation of energy demand, which eagerly calls for energy-efficient networking techniques. This project has contributed a systematical study on the modeling, control, and computing algorithms for energy efficiency optimization in wireless networking. The outcomes include a generic multidimensional optimization framework, low complexity decomposition techniques, exploitation of machine learning techniques, distributed control based on game theory, and applications in next generation cellular systems. Specifically, the findings from this project have fundamentally advanced the state of the art of energy efficient wireless networking from four main aspects.

1)      A joint optimization framework for energy efficient networking is formulated in a generic multi-dimensional resource space which involves transmission scheduling, routing, power control, and channel assignment.  With the proposal of an innovative concept of multi-dimensional transmission pattern based scheduling problem, the joint optimization problem is transformed in the linear programming domain, where low complexity decomposition techniques based on delayed column generation techniques are developed.

2)      This project has contributed two generic methodologies for exploiting deep learning in energy-efficient wireless network optimization. One is to treat the energy-efficiency optimization solutions from historical instances as training data, where meaningful latent knowledge is extracted by supervised learning for significantly mitigating the complexity in solving a new optimization instance. The other methodology is to formulate energy-efficiency related control as a constrained Markov decision process (CMDP), and an online model-free deep reinforcement learning algorithm has been developed to solve the energy-efficiency CMDP problem.

3)      The distributed control for energy efficient networking based on game theory has been studied in the context of charging management for networked electrical vehicles. The interplay between electrical vehicles and charging stations, with the communications among them facilitated by a vehicular ad hoc network, are modeled as a multi-leader multi-flower Stackelberg game. New theoretical results on Nash equilibrium and the price of anarchy have been obtained.

4)      The energy-efficient downlink precoding scheme in a heterogeneous Massive MIMO system has been studied, where a macro cell is assisted with multiple small cells. The precoder design problem is to maximize the system energy efficiency by jointly considering power control, interference management, antenna switching and user throughput in a cluster of base stations. A novel optimization algorithm combining augmented multiplier (AM) and quadratic programming (QP) has been developed to address this joint optimization with decentralized implementation.

This project seamlessly integrates studies in the areas of optimization, graph theory, linear and nonlinear programming, dual decomposition, approximation algorithms, machine learning, and wireless communication and networking. This interdisciplinary research have provided many training projects to the undergraduate and graduate students at Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT), the students from Spain and France through IIT exchange program, and some local high-school students.  Especially, this project inspired students (particularly PhD students) to pursue high-quality research with a creative, open-minded, and cross-disciplinary perspective.

The outcomes from this project have been published in top-tier conference proceedings and journals, disseminated to research communities through invited talks in both academia and industry, and leveraged to enhance graduate courses and design undergraduate research projects. This project has trained highly qualified researchers and engineers for the networking and communications industry, and produced excellent PhD graduates with creativity, dedication, and professionalism. A few students involved in this project have obtained R&D jobs in Industry and one PhD graduate started his own business.
